ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of cool insect-collecting and museum curation techniques, in addition to learning about insect orders in greater detail. It was a great way to get hands-on with the information we were learning about, and learn a lot of cool facts about insects along the way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We had lots of fieldwork and hands-on work, and very helpful and insightful reading material. The end of the semester was kind of stressful as the identifications took much longer than expected--I would have liked more instructor-guided help during that stage of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! There's so much to learn and Marta is a very enthusiastic instructor who loves teaching this material.

If you are interested in the subject this is a great course to take to get a comprehensive understanding of arthropod diversity and traits. If youre just looking to take this because of the fun field trips, be aware that youre in for a Lot of time in the lab and the trips are way more work than the average vacation. This course required a significant time commitment, but I genuinely enjoyed fighting my way through Floridian underbrush and all the other unique experiences the lab had to offer.
